Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A 3-5um Fizeau Imager for the Large Binocular Telescope
Award.AbstractNarration: This project is to develop and install a 3-5micron imaging system in the 10microns Nulling Infrared Camera now under construction at the University of Arizona for operation at the coherent focus of the Large Binocular Telescope. Having two 8.4-meter mirrors separated by a 14.4-meter baseline on a single steerable platform enables Fizeau (direct imaging) interferometry with 30 milliarcseconds full width at half maximum at 4microns over a field of view limited only by the isoplanatic angle. The Large Binocular Telescope permits unprecedented angular resolution and that combined with the system's high infrared sensitivivity, 20 and 17.5 mag at L-prime and M band respectively, will permit a broad range of astronomical applications and potential groundbreaking science. These include being able to detect warm Jupiters in nearby (d<50parsecs) young (t<1Gigagyears) systems, investigate local and distant star formation regions, and also study ultra-luminous infrared galaxies at larger redshift.

POR.DRECONTENT: This project aimed to construct a mid-infrared imager for the world's largest and most capable telescope - the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) at Mt. Graham Arizona.  The LBT is unique in the world in that it incorporates two giant 8.4-meter diameter mirrors onto a single platform.   These huge mirrors are precisely controlled (at a level corresponding to 1/100th the diameter of a human hair) to act in unison like a single telescope capable of delivering images equivalent to a 23-meter diameter aperture.   The instrument that makes this combination possible is the Large Binocular Telescope Interferometer (LBTI) constructed by the University of Arizona and funded by NASA.   The instrument constructed with the support of this grant (LMIRcam - the Lbt Mid-InfraRed Camera) resides at the "combined interferometric focus" provided by the LBTI and is meant to provide the world's best sensitivity and image resolution at mid-infrared wavelengths.  At these wavelengths warm objects glow with copious quantities of infrared light but emit  little or no visible light.   At the wavelengths where LMIRcam operates the LBT can resolve angular detail as small as 0.03 arcseconds (the angular size of a penny viewed from 70 miles away).  This capability makes LMIRcam uniquely qualified to explore the environs of forming stars where warm dust,  warm enough to glowin the infrared, provides the raw material for forming new planetary systems.  LMIRcam is also a workhorse instrument for detecting and characterizing planetary systems around other stars.  Newly formed giant planets are warm and glow in the infrared - as Jupiter did when it was young and still does at a low level today.   Finding extrasolar planets is all about "contrast" - distinguishing a faint planet from the overwhelming glow of it's parent star (the moth in the searchlight problem) - LMIRcam represents the world's best contrast capability for detecting these planets thanks to the exquisitely designed adaptive optics secondary mirrors on the LBT.   NSF support for the LMIRcam project permitted astronomers from the Universities of Virginia, Minnesota and Arizona to collaborate in the design and construction of the LMIRcam camera system to realize the promise outlined above.  The system is designed around a Teledyne Imaging Systems 2048x2048 5.2um cutoff infrared array.    Each pixel on the array corresponds to a remarkably small 0.01 arcseconds on the sky.  In operation both telescope mirrors use adaptive optics to send diffraction limited images of the target into the LBTI.   The LBTI combines these images and feeds them to LMIRcam, adjusting for the path length difference between the two primary mirrors in order to produce interference fringes.   LMIRcam commenced operation at the LBT in May 2010 and is now in regular use by most of the partners in the LBT consortium.  It is regularly producing scientific papers and, as promised, its capabilities for contrast and sensitivity at mid-infrared wavelengths are the best in the world.   With support from the NASA Origin of Solar Systems Program LMIRcam is now executing the LBT  Exozodi Exoplanet Common Hunt (LEECH) program - a direct imaging search of more than 100 nearby young stars aimed at characterizing the population of "hot jupiters" around a statistically meaningful sample of stars,  constraining modes of planetary formation. LMIRcam is thus delivering on the intellectual merit outlined in the original proposal.   At the same time, the project has achieved the broader impact of maintaining and extending US leadership in astronomy by delivering a capability unparalleled anywhere else in the world.   Another important promised broader impact of the proposal was student training in astronomical instrumentation techniques.  ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project aimed to construct a mid-infrared imager for the world's largest and most capable telescope - the Large Binocular Telescope (LBT) at Mt. Graham Arizona. The LBT is unique in the world in that it incorporates two giant 8.4-meter diameter mirrors onto a single platform. These huge mirrors are precisely controlled (at a level corresponding to 1/100th the diameter of a human hair) to act in unison like a single telescope capable of delivering images equivalent to a 23-meter diameter aperture. The instrument that makes this combination possible is the Large Binocular Telescope Interferometer (LBTI) constructed by the University of Arizona and funded by NASA. The instrument constructed with the support of this grant (LMIRcam - the Lbt Mid-InfraRed Camera) resides at the "combined interferometric focus" provided by the LBTI and is meant to provide the world's best sensitivity and image resolution at mid-infrared wavelengths. At these wavelengths warm objects glow with copious quantities of infrared light but emit little or no visible light. At the wavelengths where LMIRcam operates the LBT can resolve angular detail as small as 0.03 arcseconds (the angular size of a penny viewed from 70 miles away). This capability makes LMIRcam uniquely qualified to explore the environs of forming stars where warm dust, warm enough to glowin the infrared, provides the raw material for forming new planetary systems. LMIRcam is also a workhorse instrument for detecting and characterizing planetary systems around other stars. Newly formed giant planets are warm and glow in the infrared - as Jupiter did when it was young and still does at a low level today. Finding extrasolar planets is all about "contrast" - distinguishing a faint planet from the overwhelming glow of it's parent star (the moth in the searchlight problem) - LMIRcam represents the world's best contrast capability for detecting these planets thanks to the exquisitely designed adaptive optics secondary mirrors on the LBT. NSF support for the LMIRcam project permitted astronomers from the Universities of Virginia, Minnesota and Arizona to collaborate in the design and construction of the LMIRcam camera system to realize the promise outlined above. The system is designed around a Teledyne Imaging Systems 2048x2048 5.2um cutoff infrared array. Each pixel on the array corresponds to a remarkably small 0.01 arcseconds on the sky. In operation both telescope mirrors use adaptive optics to send diffraction limited images of the target into the LBTI. The LBTI combines these images and feeds them to LMIRcam, adjusting for the path length difference between the two primary mirrors in order to produce interference fringes. LMIRcam commenced operation at the LBT in May 2010 and is now in regular use by most of the partners in the LBT consortium. It is regularly producing scientific papers and, as promised, its capabilities for contrast and sensitivity at mid-infrared wavelengths are the best in the world. With support from the NASA Origin of Solar Systems Program LMIRcam is now executing the LBT Exozodi Exoplanet Common Hunt (LEECH) program - a direct imaging search of more than 100 nearby young stars aimed at characterizing the population of "hot jupiters" around a statistically meaningful sample of stars, constraining modes of planetary formation. LMIRcam is thus delivering on the intellectual merit outlined in the original proposal. At the same time, the project has achieved the broader impact of maintaining and extending US leadership in astronomy by delivering a capability unparalleled anywhere else in the world. Another important promised broader impact of the proposal was student training in astronomical instrumentation techniques. University of Virginia graduate student Jarron Leisenring earned his Ph.
